title: confused about laptop purchase even after reading FAQs
content:
have a budget of around 75-80k  
m3 macbook air 16-256 for 80k but worried about repair costs if any down the line.  
thinkpad e14 with core ultra 5 125u for 71k  
ideapad with core ultra 5 125h for 81k  
loq with 13450hx and 4050 for 83k

i am in cse, 2nd sem, and am really confused.  
something thats reliable for 3-4 years and can run everything that the course demands.  
suggestions would help.

comments.body:
mac is very reliable.

mac : good build quality, high repair costs  
other laptops you mentioned : not so good build quality, lower repair costs

see what fits you.

I believe like, see, MacBook rarely gets any repairs, if you get then it will definitely be expensive....where as windows of these HP Dell ASUS etc, you will get a repair atleast 6 months once again depends on your usage...and repair cost is also low....so if you see them together...repair costs are almost some, but still mac will be lil more expensive....I hope ppl get my point....I have both mac and dell, mac it's been 6yrs, no repairs nothing till now.....dell had the worst experience tho.....2x hinges (worth 1500rs) went within 3yrs....so hope ppl get my point.....

i'll recommend mac

mac storage cannot be upgraded, i dont know if 256gb storage is sufficient, maybe a senior can tell ðŸ‘€
Either go for mac or lenovo, it depends on your branch too. Usually mac isn't recommended for ece, but for cs, both should be fine.

any laptop above 40k will run everything the course demands for the next 4 years. as long as you do your ml on the cloud.

buy a laptop based on what you specifically need out of it

there's no doubt apple has the best hardware and arguably software. 

but what if i want to use another os? what if i want a second drive, or just a bigger one? more ram? that'll be 20k for every 8gb. and that's only before purchase

what if i want more ports than two USBCs.

the versatility of other laptops is what makes them better. you can decide to boot another os, you can decide to do anything

More ports : A docking station  
Another OS : Live USB running a Linux distro of your choice (again, macOS is very much like Linux)  
More Storage : A fast Samsung external SSD

There are sacrifices no matter which way you go. MacOS isn't for power users, windows/linux is, 

RAM yes. Cannot be upgraded. However, app optimisation for macOS is far better than optimisation for windows which automatically reduces RAM usage in macbooks.
256 gb storage isnt enough , if your going for mac.
